channel.title: Living in Alphabet Soup
channel.description: Just a mom with anxiety, raising children with acronym diagnoses and working in an industry full of letter lingo.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Living in Alphabet Soup is a blog and website put together by Heather Birdwell to have a place to organize her sources and definitions for all of the acronyms in her life. It has grown since the days of just being a place to put down thoughts and notes. Heather, the founder of Living in Alphabet Soup, suffers from anxiety disorder and is married to a loving husband who battles Bi-Polar Disorder and Attention Deficit Disorder. Together they have four children ranging in age from three to thirteen. Their oldest, Starbucks, battles Oppositional Defiant Disorder, as well as anxiety. Bullfrog is the next oldest and has been diagnosed with severe anxiety, but is also being monitored for autism symptoms that were formerly known as Aspergers. Monkey is the final child with an actual diagnosis. She suffers from anxiety that manifests into selective mutism and sensory processing disorder. Currently, their fourth child is a neurotypical, loving, and crazy 3-year-old little girl. In addition to juggling all the acronyms that come from the children, Heather is passionate about getting her degree in accounting and computer science. Both of those bring back lingo that is flooded with acronyms and industry specific lingo. It is her hope that this site will become a place where one can find the resources necessary for raising children with differing needs, as well as understand the terms that are used in a technological world that is growing by leaps and bounds. You can find resources for both the neurological and IT communities in Kansas City. For those who are not in the KC Metro, feel free to browse the General Mental Health Resources, You Matter Campaign, as well as the acronym wiki pages.

item.title: Conversations Actually Heard in Our House ....
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Living in my house with four children, you never know what you will hear. It can be kind of crazy, but hilarious at the same time. Here are the highlights of just one day with my kids!

Me changing Turtle ... Turtle takes off.
Monkey - NAKED BABY!!
Me - YES, naked baby. Get back here, Turtle!!
Change finished, grab Monkey's dress
Me - Come here, Monkey, time for you to get dressed.
Monkey - No! I naked baby now.
Laughter erupts
=============================

Peanut telling her friends about her sisters.
Peanut - This is Monkey. She is 2 1/2 and potty training. Doing pretty good too!
Friend - That's cool.
Peanut *pointing at me* - This is my other child ...
Me - Uh, WHAT?!
Laughter erupts
==============================

Peanut - Dad, can we get up early so that I can be at KidZone when it opens.
Dad - Um ... we will see.
Peanut - I want to play the games.
Dad - Oh is this what it is all about.
Peanut - YES!

Hours later ....

Peanut - I need my coat.
Me - Why do you need your coat right now?
Dad - Because she lays her clothes out at night. Makes mornings easier
Peanut - Yes. That's the one thing I hate about school days .... they start SO early.
*crickets*

item.title: My Stand Against Bullying!
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
I do not, nor will I EVER tolerate being bullied. I don't tolerate my kids bullying me, kids bullying other kids, or anyone being aggressive with me.


I understand that things do not always go the way you visioned them to be. But name-calling, trash talking, threats ... NEVER a way to get it to change in your direction. Bully tactics are what led me to quit working at PetSmart (which, btw, the person being the bully was finally released after a thorough investigation was done). I do not take kindly to those who think they can throw a temper fit and demand that I listen to it.

Let me fill you in on a little secret ... I let my kids have temper fits. I think it is healthy that they know it is OKAY to be mad. Not everything in life is okay. HOWEVER, with that said, there are a few rules to their temper fits.
  1. You are not allowed to destroy the house in the process.
  2. You are not allowed to call names.
  3. You are not allowed to be disrespectful.
  4. You are not allowed to throw the temper in front of me.
  5. You are not allowed to be physically or verbally abusive.
  6. You ARE allowed to come talk to me after you have completely gotten your rant over.
Guess what, folks ... it WORKS. I take that same tactic with adults. Do not threaten me, do not disrespect me, and work through your emotions. Once you have done that, then I am more than willing to work through what it is we need to.

If people do not cave to bullies ... if people walk away ... if people stand up and take the power back ... then bullies will have nothing. I firmly believe this is possible.

item.title: Because everyone needs their own day!
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
I absolutely LOVE my children. Sure their temper fits can drive me batty, and their inability to sleep at night makes for very long days ... BUT ... there is NOTHING that tops some of the things they say and do.

Monkey has been cracking us up lately. She pretends to be a dinosaur and will roar at everyone. Chasing everyone around the house and just laughing. However ... the best line we have had in a long time was made during a conversation today.

Me: Susan made me laugh yesterday.
Jer: Really? What happened?
Me: She posted the hump day camel and completely threw me off.
Jer: Y'all are weird.
Me: Yeah, told her she shouldn't post those pictures on a Tuesday.
Jer: *sigh*
Monkey: It's Twoday?
Me: No, it's Wednesday. Yesterday was Tuesday.
Monkey: My day! Twoday ... My day. I two! (picture little girl holding her two fingers up)

Jer and I just started laughing. It was too cute. Why, because everyone should have their own day!

My new photo for Tuesdays!

item.title: Talking Serious Right Now
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
USCs MSW Programs Blog Day.

*may contain hard to read information*

I like to keep my blog uplifting and down to Earth. Unfortunately, there are life events that do not always allow that to happen. Everyone knows the past year has been extremely tough on my family and I am very thankful for my husband. He was there beside me every step of the way.

Let's back up a bit.


I was SO excited to be expecting again in 2010. We had been trying for almost a year. Throughout those 9 months, life began to hit some real hard bumps. We weathered the storm but it was not without damage. I fell into a depression and it became full blown PPD (post-partum depression) shortly after Monkey was born. I tried to seek help but kept hitting roadblocks. Jeremy wasn't sure what was wrong and had no clue about PPD. We continued to weather the storm ... but not as well.

August 22, 2012 life stopped. CPS came, cops came, code enforcement came ... everyone left ... including my children. I cannot begin to tell you what that did to me. Emotionally and physically. I have had MANY people ask me how I managed to stay positive over the course of 11 months while we worked to get our children back home with us. I must say it was because of the help the state gave us and my supportive husband.

That support is not something everyone has however ... which is why September 10th is an EXTREMELY important date. It is Suicide Prevention Day. While I was never suicidal during those long, dark days ... I know many who have battled suicidal thoughts. BlogHer and many others are teaming up and talking about experiences and support for Suicide Prevention. Support to show that we understand ... life SUCKS. It is HARD and it is not always fair. Depression is something that is REAL and even if people do not talk about it, it does not mean they are not fighting it. They are not lazy ... they are not seeking attention ... they are not pessimists ... they have a void.



USCs MSW Programs Blog Day.
 
 

If you or a friend are considering suicide please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273- (8255). It is free and confidential.

 

 
RIP Don Harman - Loved by THOUSANDS around the KC Metro
 
Source

item.title: More than willing to walk for .....
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Most children are willing to walk to get to mommy or daddy ... not my Turtle. Turtle will walk for Brownsies! She only took a step but it was A STEP! She was so proud of herself too.

Today has just been most excellent for Turtle:
~ Play in the room
~ Bang on pots and pans
~ Eat diced peaches
~ Bath time with rubber ducky, strainer, and a cup
~ Very small chunk of brownie

It is hot outside but we are having fun inside!

No longer my baby

item.title: Long chaotic day
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
This morning started rushed. We didn't get things loaded that we needed to and so we missed one errand I hoped to get done. Oh well.

Jeremy came home to get me and the two littles at noon but of course I couldn't find one pair of shoes for Monkey. I had a lot of one shoe with no match. Finally found a matching set and out the door we went ... only to realize that Monkey's seat wasn't back in it's place yet.

FINALLY we were off to get the kids. Peanut had just finished lunch so Turtle, her, and I all were dropped off at KU. We did not learn much today because they decided that since Peanut didn't want her blood drawn, they were not going to see if she might have any food allergies that may be triggering her migraines. We will have to go about it in a different manner ... using a neurologist after we log everything for the next few weeks. Unfortunately, we HAVE to figure out what her triggers are so we can at least TRY to prevent migraines if possible. She is severely allergic to dust so we are getting her a cover for her mattress and she is to vacuum every couple days.

Jeremy took Bullfrog and Monkey and they went to Bullfrog's eval appointment. They wanted to see if there was anything sparking his melt downs. Fortunately (or unfortunately if we wanted something exact) there is nothing wrong with Bullfrog. He DOES have sensory problems and is very sensitive to changes, textures, tones, etc. It does make it harder for him to work in a normal family with lots of changes, but we are all now working together to help him. To reward him for the stresses of today, I took him shopping tonight. Just me & him. It was great fun!

I also picked up some empty wipe containers for a friend so be prepare for a Crafting through Pinterest post as soon as I unbury myself from my work!

item.title: Such a proud mom!
item.dc:creator: kcbusymom@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
As I continue to work behind the scenes on dealing with the effects of my postpartum depression, things are finally beginning to wrap up. I have learned so much in the last six months, but the biggest realization I have made is the fact that I had forgotten how much I love my children. Life is just not the same without them here, regardless of the fights and attitudes. I miss hearing Monkey  singing all the time, Peanut humming while doing her homework, and Bullfrog constantly talking about his YuGiOh, Bakugon, and other card games that I have no clue about!

Tonight I got the chance to watch my daughter take a big step. That step was trying out for a prestigious choir here in Kansas City. The Allegro Children's Choir is one of the best choirs Kansas City has to offer. We asked her about it a couple years ago, and she was not ready to try out for it. However, she changed her mind this year. We are at a place where we can support that desire and give her the wind under her wings so she can fly. She picks up on songs so quickly and is very receptive to being taught. Especially when it is something that she absolutely enjoys. We will find out in about a week what, if any, choir group she was accepted into.

This does not change her love for violins and photography. It also does not change her love for wanting to read American Girl books, or other historical non-fiction book. She will always be my young lady trapped in a little girl's body. The girl I want to have sit on my lap while I brush her hair. The girl I want to snuggle up to on her futon bed at night and play footsie. That little girl that has a million different facial expressions from the day she was born.

I am having a hard time believing that my little Peanut is now in double digits and becoming quite the young lady. Full of spunk, full of life, full of energy, and full of the belief that anything is possible.
